sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying rectangular loop
message_1: A rectangular loop of wire measures 4 cm by 6 cm and carries a current of 2 A. Calculate the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the loop, located 8 cm from the center of the loop.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the rectangular loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a rectangular loop at a point on its axis:

B = (μ₀ * I * a * b²) / (2 * π * (a² + z²)^(3/2))

where:
B is the magnetic field
μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A)
I is the current in the loop (2 A)
a is the length of the loop (4 cm = 0.04 m)
b is the width of the loop (6 cm = 0.06 m)
z is the distance from the center of the loop to the point on the axis (8 cm = 0.08 m)

Now, we can plug in the values and calculate the magnetic field:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 0.04 m * 0.06² m²) / (2 * π * (0.04² m² + 0.08² m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.04 m * 0.0036 m²) / ((0.0064 m² + 0.0064 m²)^(3/2))

B = (2.88 × 10^(-7) Tm²) / (0.0128 m²)^(3/2)

B ≈ 2.88 × 10^(-7) Tm² / 0.04525 m³

B ≈ 6.36 × 10^(-9) T

So, the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the loop, located 8 cm from the center of the loop, is approximately 6.36 × 10^(-9) T (Tesla).
